Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Cosmological Structure at Small Scales; From the Nature of Dark Matter and its Small-Scale Behavior to Galaxy Formation
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PI will study the history of galaxy structure formation through measurements and modeling of the small-scale matter power spectrum from the Lyman-alpha forest and through quantifying the uncertainties in statistical measures of galaxy halo occupation distributions. Further the PI will apply these methods to current and upcoming data. The projects will integrate research and education through training and developing graduate students through supervised research on the proposed projects. The project will outreach to high school students locally near the University of Maryland through contact and integration with science fair project work, which is under way. A primary new effort proposed is the development of an interactive question and answer program for high school teachers at the University of Maryland Center for Fundamental Physics through a web-based wiki interface. The aspects of this proposal of cosmological large-scale structure (on small scales) through the Lyman-alpha forest and galaxy clustering statistics will be taken up by two separate students or by a single student. In addition, these projects will foster the further scientific development of a postdoctoral research scholar supported by this award.

Highlights of Intellectual Merit

The project has had significant outcomes on the study of the fundamental constituents of our physical universe, primarily focused this year on the nature of dark matter. There exist two high-energy photon candidat signals of dark matter annihilation and decay. One is a very high significance detection of gamma-ray photons from the Milky Way Galactic Center (GC) that has the morphology, flux and spectrum that would be expected from dark matter annihilation. Our group independently detected this signal with high significance in 2012, and has studied it extensively this year. We found that the Galactic Center not only harbors the excess associated with what could be prompt photons from dark matter annihilation, but also secondary photons in bremsstrahlung and inverse Compton processes that could be due to the same dark matter source. See Image 2. We find that stellar remnants can also provide a population of high-energy electron cosmic rays to produce the observed signal. This was published in Abazajian et al. JCAP 1507 (2015) 07, 013. Further work has looked at the consistency between dark matter interpretations of the GC excess and the lack of a signal in dwarf galaxies. [preprint arXiv:1510.06424].

Another, independent, high-significance signal of high-energy photons were discovered by X-ray astronomers in 2014 coming from clusters of galaxies and the nearby Andromeda (M31) galaxy. An unidentified line at 3.5 keV in energy was seen to have flux proportional to the dark matter density within the field of view of the observations. This is consistent with dark matter decay. The astronomers discovered the signal with methods proposed by Abazajian and collaborators in 2001. An extensive analysis of the production of the leading dark matter candidate, a sterile neutrino, that could produce this signal was studied with collaborators. Three of the signals from other work are shown in Image 1, with the model parameters which we studied shown as stars. Interestingly, the candidate for dark matter produces structure that could alleviate problems with galactic dynamics in the Local Group of Galaxies [preprint arXiv:1507.06655]. Two sets of numerical simulations for the candidate dark matter are ongoing in collaboration between Abazajian and other researchers.

 

Highlights of Broader Impact

Broader impacts included the mentoring of undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs. A Cal State Fullerton undergraduate worked in 2014 on the gamma-ray excess in the Galactic Center, producing a visualization of the GCE being revealed with removal of foreground emission layers (published on YouTube at http://is.gd/qkcHuT). Abazajian is on the steering committee and is a mentor for the NSF S-STEM funded Cal-Bridge program, which aims to increase underrepresented minorities and women entering graduate school in astronomy and physics at UC's and other universities, from Cal State. In 2015, Abazajian mentored an undergraduate from Reed College, who worked on neutrino cosmology topics.  Abazajian also directly advised two graduate students and mentored two others.
